content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" is a bill that excludes space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced or provided in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from services performed in outer space, interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to production or services in outer space. Telecommunications services provided from earth orbit are exempt from this exclusion. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes certain space-related services from gross income, including telecommunications services from earth orbit, weather or earth observation satellite services, and property transportation to or from outer space. Wages received by employees are also exempt from this exclusion. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income, including wages of employees. Space-related income is determined by proportional allocation between space-based and earth-based activities for products produced partly in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income, including wages of employees. The term 'produced' includes various methods like created, fabricated, developed, grown, manufactured, extracted, processed, cured, and aged. Any product manufactured in outer space and launched from and returned to Earth within the United States or manufactured at a facility in outer space owned by one or more United States persons is excluded from tariffs. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from federal taxes. Products manufactured in outer space by U.S. persons are also exempt from federal tariffs. The benefits of this act will phase out gradually after 2012. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from federal taxes and federal tariffs on products made in outer space by U.S. persons. Benefits will phase out gradually after 2012. Amendments to the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code are made. SPACE COMPANY INVESTMENT CREDIT," provides a credit for the purchase of qualified stock in a domestic C corporation with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from federal taxes and tariffs on products made in outer space by U.S. persons. A new section, "SEC. 45G. SPACE COMPANY INVESTMENT CREDIT," provides a credit for the purchase of qualified stock in a domestic C corporation meeting specific criteria related to annual gross receipts and space-based business activities. The term 'qualified stock' in a domestic C corporation is defined as stock acquired by the taxpayer at its original issue in exchange for money or other property, if the corporation is a qualified space company at the time of issuance. The term 'qualified stock' in a domestic C corporation is stock acquired at original issue in exchange for money or other property, or as compensation for services provided, with an active business requirement for the corporation. The taxpayer's holding period for qualified stock in a C corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to the purchase of its own stock by the corporation. Recapture may occur within a 10-year period ending on the date qualified stock was purchased. The tax credit for qualified stock in a C corporation may be recaptured if the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of purchase. This provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. The tax credit for qualified stock in a C corporation may be recaptured if the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of purchase. This provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. Amendments are made to the general business credit section to include a space company investment credit. Amendments are made to the general business credit section to include a space company investment credit, with restrictions on carrying back the credit before January 1, 2004. Amendments are made to the general business credit section to include a space company investment credit under section 45G(a) of the tax code. The amendments made by this section introduce a Space Company Investment Credit under section 45G, effective for costs incurred after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a Capital Gains Exclusion is added for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of Qualified Space Corporations under section 1203 of the tax code. Gross income excludes gain from selling stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space. A qualified space corporation is defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90 percent of expenses attributable to the active conduct of such business. This term excludes corporations providing services, products, or articles as described in section 140(b)(2). The amendment excludes gains from the sale of stock of qualified space corporations. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
